content: The Bush tax cuts, enacted in 2001 and 2003, were set to expire at the end of 2010. This included lower rates for long-term capital gains and dividends, with a 0% tax rate for certain taxpayers. Without legislative action, capital gains tax rates would have increased to 20% and dividends would be taxed at ordinary rates. President Obama proposed retaining lower rates for lower- and middle-income taxpayers but increasing rates for higher-income individuals. The tax rates were extended through 2012 by the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance. Obama proposed to retain the 15% and 0% tax rates for lower- and middle-income taxpayers in his budget outlines for FY2010 and FY2011. He suggested taxing dividends and capital gains at 20% for married couples with income over $250,000 and single taxpayers with income over $200,000. The final resolution in 2013 was to tax capital gains for higher-income individuals at higher rates, with thresholds set at $480,050 for married couples and $453,350 for singles in 2018.
